commentBody: Began and ended Caturday with cat breeds (or fur patterns)!

"Do I have to use a period here?"
"Yep! Dot's the way it is!"

(Ooof, that pun will leave a mark.)
fun and easy Sunday, a personal best. When the guides say Sunday is supposed to be like Wednesday but bigger, I usually disagree, but today was right on!

[ ?  Superb ]






OUTSTANDING BEYOND QUESTION
I‚Äôm done and only four comments are in! A record for me!
Fun and easy‚Ä¶

This puzzle was especially fun for me to complete. I just had hip surgery last week and my daughter, who lives in Australia and is over visiting, was able to help me with the house chores while I completed it. Whilst I have not personally heard of ‚Äúsump‚Äù before, the author‚Äôs ‚Äúsumptuous‚Äù choice of words helped me in my endeavour. Also my dog died. Looking forward to more from the author.
So fun, so nice and the right side of easy. Thank you!
What? Nobody complaining yet about the rebuses?

Hopefully others have as much fun as I did and achieve...

AVERAGE
√ó√ó
An easy breezy puzzle.  Gonna head on over to the archive and try a Sunday from the 90s.

Spent far too long thinking 'Average killers' was BEES ie average grade/killer bees. 

Otherwise a lovely solve before bed on a Saturday night. Yup. That's me. The party animal. Roar.

Nice puzzle! I like the theme, especially because I was able to use it to crack some of the theretofore opaque clues. I don‚Äôt like that it took me a relatively long time to solve it. I had more ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what that might be‚Äù moments and more answers that I had to change than I typically do when solving a Sunday puzzle. If you‚Äôre interested, I wrote a longer review for Diary of a Crossword Fiend. https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/03/29/sunday-march-30-2025/ Thanks, Mr. Seigel!
Fun puzzle and even beat my average while watching UConn impress.
My second ever 14 day streak, and my best month ever with (assuming I get the Monday) 27 Gold Stars
I struggle with this type of (well all types) rebus puzzles but I was able to get a couple of these fairly easily. A very enjoyable puzzle. Thanks!

There is a satisfying moment when you try a fill and it slides firmly into place with what you already have that is unlike any other. A small affirmation that you have correctly READ BETWEEN THE LINES.  A lot of smiles this time, as I jumped around puzzle, and I finished it feeling quite elated.

Thank you for the buzz I got from your elegant construction, Simeon Seigel.  I may have wept through some of your Thursdays, but this one was a honey.  (Full disclosure: I'm still trying to figure out why RAIL was right.)

This is pushing what might be considered punctuation, but I‚Äôm sharing it because I want to see if the symbol shows correctly:

Existing
     ‚ôÆ




SUPERNATURAL BEING

I liked the puzzle except for my personal pet peeve‚Äîthose are hyphens not dashes. They are too short even to be en-dashes. Maybe they didn‚Äôt want to confuse with the lines later, but they have periods and points used interchangeably so why not dashes and lines? I wouldn‚Äôt care so much for the puzzle‚Äôs sake, but in real life people use hyphens instead of dashes all the time, it‚Äôs terribly annoying to read, and I wish at least the New York Times would try to teach people the difference. Oh well, as I said it‚Äôs my own pet peeve.
It's a good thing I do the mini a lot more than the big one, because I am truly amazed that so many thought this puzzle was easy.  How did everyone know what a Stoat is?

I‚Äôm confused‚Ä¶why are commenters talking about rebuses? My understanding was that this term (in crosswords ant least) refers to puzzles where the solution one enters involves symbols or multiple letters into a single square. Not puzzles where the hint uses symbols as a form of wordplay. Am I missing something? Is there another layer to this puzzle I‚Äôm not noticing?

I believe this was record time for me on a Sunday which is too bad - I like to linger over the Sunday puzzle. Clever theme - 35A was the last to fall for me. Originally had ROAD at 23A and a few others threw me off balance but overall enjoyed the solve. üòÉ
Nice fun puzzle
I enjoy themes like these

‚ö´
It


NOT TO PUT TOO FINE A POINT ON IT


Fun puzzle.  All of the themers were excellent, especially since there were not ‚Äú‚àû Options‚Äù

INFINITE POSSIBILITIES
First, ‚ÄúWhat is OBVS?‚Äù. But then, ‚ÄúDuh!‚Äù.

I thoroughly enjoyed this one!!!  A fun theme and I did lots of giggling when I shifted my thinking and got the answers from the many less-than-straightforward (but all completely sensible) clues.  Thanks Simeon - from my point of view the perfect Sunday puzzle.

This was an enjoyable outing.

Two clues gave me pause for thought -
Feature of a safe landing &
Group in "a pension fund."  (no IRA there!)

Hope the week ahead is a good one for all.

Happy Puzzling!
I was a bit surprised to get the happy music after finally figuring out the NE corner. I had KEN penciled to come back to since no way that was correct. Still don‚Äôt COMPREHEND the clue.

I guess it‚Äôs just me but I have a mistake somewhere and for the life of me I cannot find it. I guess I just have to give up since it doesn‚Äôt appear to be any kind of glitch but boy that‚Äôs frustrating. Bizarre.

The trick was quite interesting, and definitely much more so than last week's dad-joke "wordplay".

The section with AUGER (I've seen the word but don't know what it means), BLADE (I fixated on stiletto being a shoe thing) and TRAP (I'm hopeless with music genres) was beyond me - I did 80% of the puzzle myself, but the top section remained largely blank, with that one area a complete mystery. I first enabled autocheck, and then revealed the AU of AUGER. 

Good thing about the autocheck, too, as it revealed a typo elsewhere I would never have seen myself - one of the things I dislike about the Sunday crossword is how hard it is to spot mistakes in a grid as large as this. I rarely get a gold star on Sunday simply because I make typos and can't be bothered to look for them. Not caring about a streak saves me a lot of grief.
My first guess for the Pamana Island clue was TYPO but it turned out it wasn't mine.
Just a fun puzzle top to bottom. I like architecture but had never heard the term "oriel" - thanks for an edifying inclusion!
Knew this was going to be a fun one when I saw the constructor‚Äôs name. Honestly this was really tame compared to some of his Thursday brain destroyers.

I love all rebuses, but traditional visual rebuses are my favorites. This was a perfect diversion to get me through a violent storm and distract me from all the thunder and lightning. (Fortunately, nothing hit the ROOF.) Thanks, Simeon!
YAY!! I did it without looking at any of the down clues! Only used the crosses. Phew! Never managed that on a Sunday before. Finished in 59.20‚Ä¶ a long breakfast!

I enjoyed this puzzle‚Äî not surprisingly for one by Simeon Seigel! I found the gimmick clever, if not particularly difficult to deduce. 

For 52A, I briefly had ‚ÄúSold‚Ä¶‚Äù rather than BUYS‚Ä¶: wondered if anyone else fell into that trap? I found it interesting that my phrase could be read as both synonym or antonym of the correct answer. Tbh, though, I think i‚Äôve only heard ‚ÄúSold on‚Äù rather than ‚ÄúSold BY‚Äù! Still, it made perfect sense to me until EBB made things clear.

I had never heard of Pamana Island, and was chagrined to realize how distorted is my view of world geography. I never would have thought that the southernmost point in Asia was in Indonesia, and *only* 750 miles below the equator. When I looked at a map after completion of the puzzle, I saw how skewed was my mental image of how the continents aligned themselves!

That was a lot of fun. Not all that easy for me, of course, and did cheat a bit early on. But catching on to the trick was just a terrific 'aha' moment and then really enjoyed pondering and working the crosses to finally have each of them dawn on me.

Was VERY surprised to see  that almost all of the theme answers were debuts, as a lot of them were pretty familiar terms or phrases. 

And.. of course I had a puzzle find today. Another one that was all in the clues. I'll put that in a reply. 

...
Delightful. Thanks Simeon.
Seuss was the maiden name of Geisel‚Äòs mother. She was the daughter of German immigrants. The name would indeed be pronounced to rhyme with voice.

When I see Simeon Seigel's name, I prepare to have my brain melted. 

I guess he has a gentle side.

Still, it was an enjoyable solve with an amusing theme.

Six of the seven themers were debuts, which surprised me considering how common the phrases are.

A delightful crossword.
Couple of culture clashes - 
# Believes
I thought # means 'number' so instead of no. 6 it's #6?
BAE?
CLAM?
I assume DINE AND DASH is an idiom, haven't heard that, or is it the name of a type of restaurant?

I wouldn't think of POSH as clued here, more tending towards a criticism; POSH Spice's name was ironic, because she didn't smile and was considered 'snooty' or arrogant.
Ok, I give up complaining when trick puzzles appear on any day other than Thursday.   But please let us at least have Sundays' puzzles be gimmick-free?   It's really a letdown.

With this puzzle I hit my first 1000-day streak.

I‚Äôm choosing to think of these 1000 days retrospectively as small acts of anti-fascism. 

Here‚Äôs to the pursuit of knowledge, truth, and community. And the joy of crosswords!

Now that's what I call Happy Hour -- 58:14, to be exact.  Fun and clever.  

And now we know what an ORIEL is.

I felt a shiver of excitement upon seeing Simeon‚Äôs name atop the puzzle.  Simeon, purveyor of devilish wit, surprise, and how-did-he-do-that?

The devilish element today, IMO, was in the cluing.  Oh, I enjoyed the theme, especially the brilliant PRE- and POST- theme answers, given their clues.  But the puzzle‚Äôs cluing ‚Äì this I savored. Wordplay was effusive, and wordplay-lover I was in my happy place.  

My sense is that Simeon takes time and care with every clue; that he hangs out with every answer until a clue passes his bar.  

So many of his clues have never been seen before in the major crossword outlets. Examples: [Feature of a safe landing, perhaps] for RAIL, [Average killers] for DEES, [Reproductive systems?] for COPIERS, and the marvelous misdirect [Not partial] for ENTIRE.  Terrific wordplay in all of these.   

This was a splendid outing, and once again, I am so grateful for what you bring to the box, Simeon.  Thank you!
A solid Sunday puzzle that was fun but not that difficult. I enjoyed the theme a lot.

This was a fun puzzle. A little more challenging than the typical Sunday puzzle, at least for me or at least until I caught on to the gimmick. Even then the cluing wasn't as obvious as many Sundays. A cut above, I thought. Even if it does include "obvs."

Not my SPEEDIEST Sunday solve, but quite fun.

ear worm theme song?

, color-changing reptile

see the constructor‚Äôs name,
and open up a
Christmas morning of clueing.

I know it‚Äôll be fun.
I‚Äôm certain it will abound with wit and humor.
I am also slightly afraid.
But it‚Äôs Sunday, so probably gentle.

Mr Seigel delivered.
Santa Seigel. Stuffed this Sunday stocking
with sly, Seuss (Soice!), batsuits, banhmi‚Ä¶
Ah, me!

I dare say I have a soft spot for this constructor.
Obvs.

Happy Sunday, Wordplay world!
Fun puzzle!  Was stuck for quite a while by entering THATSnotthePOINT.

This was great! Thank you, Simeon.
I'm not too crazy about 9A, but otherwise perfect!
A lovely stroll through Simon's Sunday crossword park. Merci!
I thought Garfield was a marmalade (ginger) cat. My beautifully fluffy grey, black and brown stripey Bella is a tabby.
Railed it.

enjoyable and challenging.  

Thank you Simeon
really enjoyed the way this came together for me, and loved the rebus puzzle style theme! great sunday 10/10
Okay, I know I'm losing it somewhat, but wasn't there a different photo of the Emmy statue last night and earlier today?

So much love for this puzzle!! üòç I always love solving a good rebus. Thank you, Simeon, for this stellar work. I am just 99 days away from reaching a 4 year consecutive streak and this was such a pleasure along that path ü§©
Crossing a long dead diplomat with a rare protein is just cruel. Rusk/prions?

Oh, what fun!  I was just muddling around, putting things in and then regretting what I'd done...
The light dawned at 99A (as always, a breakthrough at the bottom works best for me) and after that it was even MORE fun.

I really wanted "Hit the DECK" and still feel a bit pouty over it, plus  the Medicare PART could be B or (arrgh those for-profit DISAdvantage plans) C, but I opted for C, hoping George Clooney would never consent to a CAT SUIT...though one never knows.  (We don't go to movies these days; the volume level is literally painful to my ears.)  

Hat is off to Simeon Seigel (which I instinctively want to pronounce "SIGH-gull" but suspect it may be Americanized into "SEE-gull.")

Oh, for Pete's sake.
I but BAT SUITS, then mis-typed the entry

I really enjoyed this puzzle because the gimmick was so helpful to figure out fairly early in the solve. Each instance was then an opportunity to drop in a lot of letters. The one area that beat me was the NE, where I didn't know ORIEL, and had SHY for 17D. That combination made 16D completely inscrutable to me for some reason, leaving me grasping for potential abbreviations of chess piece names.

The trivia on DRSEUSS was a great little nugget to share!

Seigel and Geisel are anagrams. Coincidence?

Obvs.

I loved this puzzle!

FIRST AMONG EQUALS

Feeling pretty good now. At first, I was able to fill in about six, and I felt worthless, hopeless, and caffeineless. Fortunately, the theme isn't ridiculously cryptic, and once I got it, I was able to get the rest. Now a semblance of self-esteem has returned.

I loved it.  Cute gimmick & I solved it in record time for a Sunday.
No hesitations, no typos - just whoosh with a smile.  
Thank you for a fun Sunday, Simeon :)
Square 55 had me thinking ‚Äúok, boomer‚Äù

Today I was saved by SLOP at 94A. After entering that word, I realized that the SLOP I already had for 12 D "Apply haphazardly, with 'on'" had to be wrong. Which also meant that ARNO wasn't the fraudster and a BAHRMI is not a Vietnamese baguette.

Can't recall this ever happening to me before---where the reappearance of an answer told me that an earlier appearance had to be wrong.

The themers and their clues were all clever. Having .[Not this] for THATSBESIDETHEPOINT was certainly the most obscure. But "[Not this]" become's "that", and we have "That" is beside the point. Can't think of any better clue for this one.

Some CRUD was the price paid for having seven long themers, but it wasn't too bad. Though one wonders why the constructor and editor went with VEINY crossing TAYE. At the end of the puzzle, how about just VEINS and TASE? Probably biased since I have no idea who TAYE is, and think "veiny" is pretty dubious.

Decent Sunday puzzle and a solid construction, but not a real favorite.
Can someone explain why "Chess pieces" is "MEN"?

I'm grateful to Ms. Lovinger for including the link to Frank Longo's 1995 puzzle.  There are a few real gems in it, but what stood out for me was how much harder the fill was, how much more information we were expected to know or derive from the crossings.  The theme entries in today's puzzle were much more obvs than in the older one, and fwiw I think I preferred the older level of difficulty.  Ymmv.
Finished just under an hour. A delightful puzzle with some solid chuckles + misdirects. I had ADHERE for 61A but was a little confused what an ASIDE was doing on an album‚Ä¶

I messed up with PDS(private detective)  instead of PIS and add 
instead of AID Made sense to me and broke my record. Great puzzle though
23:05.  Such fun once I got the clue theme!

I had never bothered to wonder what the Emmy statuette was holding. Now I know.

I clung to OBVi for far too long.

And I couldn't get an airplane image out of my head to figure out why a RAIL would signify a safe landing. I had to look that up after I finished.

The themed entries, of course, were fun and clever.
Great puzzle.  Had trouble with some of the fill but love the theme.

Great puzzle. Once I sussed out the theme, things got considerably easier. Unlike Caitlin, I actually found 87-Across to be the easiest of the theme entries, probably because I'd already figure out at least 3 others by then. 

The NE corner gave me a bit of a problem--I originally thought Garfield and others were "calicos." Duh.

* ‚ÄúWell, I never!‚Äù

Asterix, the Gaul.
Cool theme, fill was tricky.
Great puzzle - I‚Äôve solved the bottom half. I‚Äôm struggling with the top half especially the themed clues. The DINEANDDASH is fun to type - just so we never experience it :-)

I don‚Äôt if this has been raised as I haven‚Äôt read all the comments but a minor correction here: although a four-letter star with #1 hits over seven decades certainly had to be Cher, yet having started her singing career singing backup for Phil Spector (1950s) then half of the duo Sony and Cher (1960s), as a solo artist, Cher  only achieved #1 hits in the 1970s starting with Gypsies, Tramps, and Thieves in 1971.

Re: Dr. Seuss 
If you think of pronouncing Seuss in the German fashion, it‚Äôs more like Zoice which is apparently how his mother pronounced it as her maiden name.

Solved the Sunday puzzle in a little over an hour which is pretty good for me considering that I don‚Äôt look things up and I don‚Äôt reveal letters. The theme was pretty good too! The one thing that I was mad about was the answer to the informal term for a dollar. Given that it was 4 letters, I was sure that the answer was BUCK instead of CLAM. I‚Äôve NEVER said or possibly even heard someone say, ‚ÄúI won 20 CLAMs off the scratch off ticket‚Äù. Perhaps it‚Äôs just my neck of the woods, but CLAM doesn‚Äôt make sense to me at all lol! So glad no ‚Äúpoliticians‚Äù weren‚Äôt involved either! I‚Äôll gladly type ETON instead of the L after the E but before the O and N. Anyways, thanks again and I hope you‚Äôre all enjoying your Sunday Funday my fellow NYTers and Namaste!!

Goodness; that was tough but ultimately satisfying. I had to fight to get 99.9% of the grid filled, but each completed clue gave me a nice aha moment. Revealing the theme didn‚Äôt help much until the grid was complete. Enjoyed the journey.
This one was ‚Äújust right‚Äù for me. Not easy breezy, but not full of trivia I am forced to look up, either. Clever theme, totally solvable with no lookups, just a little perseverance! Well done!

Well that was fun! By the time I got to completing the NE corner and the final special clue, I had a good chuckle with how clever "that" one was in particular. Learned some new words (ken), slang (obvs) and trivia along the way too. Not sure I'd ever get used to saying, "Dr. Zoice", but it'll be amusing to try, and likely annoyingly nerdy to others when I do.
Very enjoyable puzzle. Figured it out at 52A BUYS [,] BY THE POUND.

This was a lot of fun, and a good distraction on a day when I‚Äôm in a lot of pain üò£ (long story which won‚Äôt interest you). I jumped around the puzzle a lot, looking for as much low hanging fruit as I could find. The first themer I got was the one for ‚Äú‚ÄîPERUSE‚Äî‚Äú and then was able to go back and suss out some of the others. The title of the puzzle was some help. Thanks for the challenge Simeon Siegel.
So much fun and exactly the light diversion that I needed today. Thanks a ton, Simeon!

Really fun. I like this kind of theme. Caught it fast. Then had to fly-speck. Oops - had "plions" and "Lusk". Hmm yeah I think his name was RUSK. 
Thanks, Simeon!
Reproductive systems was my favorite. This was a very fine Sunday outing.
This was a fun one. Anyone else keep reading 3 down as Weasley family member? Kept trying Ginny and Percy!

Wonderful puzzle! I haven't had a chance to read through the comments to

I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle.  Thank you so much Simeon.  Favorite clue:  30D (Piece of mind?)
Close buy no cigar. Loved it any way!

Neither of my BILs is (or was) sketchy. But Saturday‚Äôs I DON‚ÄôT CARE reminded me of my brother-in-law Milt and his frustration with the Hougland family‚Äôs inability to decide on something as simple as where to eat dinner. (‚ÄúOh, wherever is fine with me.‚Äù ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù Etc., etc.)

RAIL for a safe landing on a staircase.


(The constructor is an architect.)

@Barry Ancona 
Thanks!  You'd think I'd have got that, having typed reams of architectural specs (I even knew when to point out to a draftsman that what he wrote was not what he meant).  In olden times, specs were written by hand, then produced on a machine called a typewriter!  The first primitive word processors slowed me down, but I could see that storing chunks of specs would be valuable. I flew off to Paris, had a job there for a while at a tours agency, then came back home.  (I still can't figure that one out.)
@Cat Lady Margaret -- Hah!  That's terrific!

@Cat Lady Margaret 

I‚Äôm not a musician. Don‚Äôt you presume that a note is a natural unless it‚Äôs marked as a sharp or a flat? Why do you need a symbol that means natural?

@Eric Hougland 

If a piece of music is in a key that has specific sharps and flats (most of them), you‚Äôll see it in the key signature at the beginning, after the clef. If a particular note, say C, is supposed to be played as C sharp every time it appears, the natural sign indicates specific notes that are to be played as a C natural. 

I‚Äôm sure DC could explain it more precisely, but that‚Äôs the general idea. 

(I‚Äôm also not a musician.)

@Eric Hougland

It‚Äôs because music is written in various keys. The key of C major has no sharps or flats, but most other keys have at least one sharp or flat.  The key signature is identified on the left of each line of the staff.  The key of D major, as in Pachelbel‚Äôs Canon in D, has an F sharp and a C sharp.  In order to stay in the right key, the musician must play every D and C as sharp.   

Thus, when the music needs an adjustment to a note, called an accidental, you might use a sharp, flat, or natural sign, depending n the note and the key the piece was written in.  If I recall correctly, these accidental signs only impact the note they appear next to.  

Hope this helps.  It‚Äôs been years since I read music.  I‚Äôm sure that David Connell could do a much better job explaining this.  

By the way, great write up over at Crossword Fiend!

@JCA 

"In order to stay in the right key, the musician must play every D and C as sharp."

If I'm understanding you, Elle and Steve L correctly,  you meant to say "every F and C," no?

Reading all these helpful replies has reminded me that I sort of knew this already, even though my own experience in reading music didn't get much further than Every Good Boy Deserves Fudge.

Thanks for reading my Fiend review. The Sunday NYT puzzle is just a temporary gig. But I plan to continue writing up Brendan Emmett Quigley's Monday and Thursday puzzles. (If anyone is looking for more crosswords to solve, BEQ's are often fun.)

@Eric Hougland

Oops!  Yes, you‚Äôre correct!  Thank you for catching my typo.

How fun to wake up and find a mini seminar in music notation!
Eric: as a singer, I will also scribble in a natural sign in my score if the piece is in a key with lots going on and I need a reminder about a certain note.

@Cat Lady Margaret 

I do exactly the same thing, or if the note isn't what I expected (even though it's correct). Same with flats and sharps.

@Elle 

Absolutely correct!

@Eric Hougland the natural symbol is required in two common instances: if the note has received a sharp or flat accidental earlier in the SAME measure, or if the key signature of the piece labels that note as sharp or flat throughout but one particular measure needs that note to be natural.   
Funny enough, I‚Äôm writing this comment during my kids‚Äô piano lessons :0)
Oops, sorry, my phone didn‚Äôt load all the comments. Didn‚Äôt realize this question had been very thoroughly answered already!

@John Peil 

Don‚Äôt worry about repeating what‚Äôs already been said. With this archaic comment system, that happens all the time. 

I appreciate your taking the time to answer my question. 

I hope your kid appreciates the piano lessons. I am  the fifth of seven children. All my older siblings got piano lessons. My younger brother and I were spared/deprived, with because money was tight with more hungry kids or because my mom was tired of arguing with her children about music lessons. 

The irony is that I love listening to music, probably more than any of my subs, but have only the vaguest idea of how it actually works.

@Eric Hougland LOL!  Thank you for being so gracious. I hear you on the money and the time and the arguing. I‚Äôve just heard so many parents over the years lament that they allowed their children to stop playing because it was such a hassle. I decided to tell my four little ones that piano is obligatory. @Eric Hougland It took so long to train myself out of two spaces after a period!

I recently had to create a style guide at work that defined how we use dashes vs. hyphens, including how to type them, and through that process learned the shortcut for getting an em dash in Microsoft Word is to type two hyphens between the words, no spaces. So I have adopted that typing convention for em dashes even when using software or devices that won‚Äôt autocorrect it.

@Eric Hougland

lol that‚Äôs my other pet peeve. I‚Äôm a physician, but I work in IT helping providers with medical record templates‚Äîand I‚Äôm constantly having to edit what they send me when they use two spaces instead of one‚Äîno longer necessary in today‚Äôs world. But old habits are hard to break.

@SP

@SP

@Eric Hougland Agreed...except I used to work in digital data publishing. To avoid problems with distributors who were re-delimiting, reformatting, and rewriting our text, we stuck to simple clear text (no dashes, no double quotes, no tabs or indents, no bullets, etc.).

@Steve C. - Stoat was a gimme for me as a children‚Äôs librarian. The villains in Kenneth Graham‚Äôs Wind in the Willows are the weasels and the stoats. @Steve C.

@Stephen the term "rebus" outside of the crossword world refers to those word puzzles where there's a little icon or drawing to refer to a word.  That's akin to what's going on in this puzzle, with the punctuation marks being replaced by their names written out.  The word rebus itself, like many words in any crossword puzzle, can have multiple meanings depending on context.
N.B. There are no rebuses in the grid.

@Barry Ancona 
Every single theme clue is a rebus, but in the usual meaning of the word instead of the narrow specialist technical NYT Crossword-ese meaning!

Per Merriam-Webster [emphasis added]: "rebus - a representation of words or syllables by pictures of objects or by <> "

Having the symbol # in the clue represent the word "pound" in the answer is an example of using a symbol who's name resembles the intended word, right? That make it a rebus.

@Barry Ancona. Might I suggest that in your description of the earlier entries about rebuses you are wrong. My entry was specifically meant to refer to the rebuses in the clues. @Terry‚Äôs had the phrase ‚Äúthis type of rebus, (as well as others)‚Äù   Seems he also was referring to the clues.

@Barry Ancona. PS. We‚Äôve had similar discussions previously. 
PPS. There are some of us who use English beyond crosswordese.
@Barry Ancona. PPPS.  The clues are part of the crossword, and so are available for commment.
